Established in 2018, the club began playing in the [[Eastern Conference (MLS)|Eastern Conference]] of [[Major League Soccer]] (MLS) during the [[2020 Major League Soccer season|2020 season]]. The club garnered international attention prior to its founding because of club president and co-owner [[David Beckham]] and again in 2023 when eight-time [[Ballon d'Or]] and [[2022 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] winner [[Lionel Messi]] signed for the club on a free transfer. Following the signing, the club won its first major trophy, the expanded [[2023 Leagues Cup]], the North American zonal competition for the [[CONCACAF]] region. == History == === Expansion === In The announcement represented part of a larger MLS expansion that would increase its number of teams to 26 by 2020 and 30 after that. Since Beckham's original announcement of his intention to place a team in Miami in 2014, [[Orlando City SC|Orlando City]], [[New York City FC]], [[Atlanta United FC|Atlanta United]], [[Minnesota United FC|Minnesota United]], [[Los Angeles FC]], and [[FC Cincinnati]] have all begun MLS play. Paul McDonough was hired as sporting director effective August 4.{{Cite web | title=Miami MLS hires Paul McDonough from Atlanta to be Sporting Director | author=Tom Bogert | work=MLSsoccer.com | date=August 2, 2018 | access-date=August 15, 2018 | url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/08/02/miami-mls-hires-paul-mcdonough-sporting-director | archive-date=August 16, 2018 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180816061724/https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/08/02/miami-mls-hires-paul-mcdonough-sporting-director | url-status=live }} The team's ownership group was later renamed Miami Freedom Park LLC. Monterrey]] manager [[Diego Alonso]] was announced as the club's inaugural head coach.{{cite web|url=https://www.intermiamicf.com/en/post/2019/12/30/inter-miami-cf-selects-diego-alonso-first-ever-head-coach-club-history|title=Inter Miami CF Selects Diego Alonso as First-Ever Head Coach in Club History|publisher=Inter Miami CF|date=December 30, 2019|access-date=December 30, 2019|archive-date=December 30, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191230162511/https://www.intermiamicf.com/en/post/2019/12/30/inter-miami-cf-selects-diego-alonso-first-ever-head-coach-club-history|url-status=live}}{{cite news|url=https://www.miamiherald.com/sports/mls/inter-miami/article238819133.html|title=Inter Miami 'blocks out noise,' hires Uruguayan Diego Alonso as first head coach|work=The Miami Herald|first=Michelle|last=Kaufman|date=December 30, 2019|access-date=December 30, 2019|archive-date=March 4, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200304220104/https://www.miamiherald.com/sports/mls/inter-miami/article238819133.html|url-status=live}} === Early years (2020–2023) === [[File:Gonzalo Higuaín 2019.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Argentine striker [[Gonzalo Higuaín]] signed with Miami in 2020]] Inter Miami's first MLS game was played on March 1, 2020, losing 1–0, away to [[Los Angeles FC]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.goal.com/en/news/vela-and-lafc-give-beckhams-inter-miami-a-lesson-on-the/tur7fix5wgsc1df1sz58hfuoh|title=Vela and LAFC give Beckham's Inter Miami a lesson on the importance of a superstar scorer {{!}} Goal.com|website=www.goal.com|access-date=March 2, 2020|archive-date=March 2, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200302011751/https://www.goal.com/en/news/vela-and-lafc-give-beckhams-inter-miami-a-lesson-on-the/tur7fix5wgsc1df1sz58hfuoh|url-status=live}} [[Designated Player Rule|Designated Player]] [[Rodolfo Pizarro]] scored the first goal in Inter Miami history the following game on March 7, in a 2–1 loss to [[D.C. In 2021, the Mas brothers finalized a buyout to take over majority ownership of the team from Claure and Son.{{cite web | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/devinseanmartin/2023/06/07/who-is-jorge-mas-the-billionaire-owner-behind-lionel-messis-new-team/?sh=4dec22144f2f | title=Who is Jorge Mas, the Billionaire Owner Behind Lionel Messi's New Team? | website=[[Forbes]] }} On May 28, 2021, MLS announced that it would sanction Inter Miami CF, owner Jorge Mas, and former sporting director Paul McDonough for violating roster rules during the 2020 season. The club had signed [[Blaise Matuidi]] and [[Andrés Reyes (footballer, born 1999)|Andrés Reyes]] using targeted [[allocation money]] (TAM) to comply with salary cap requirements and avoid using its three [[Designated Player Rule|Designated Player]] slots, but were found to have exceeded the TAM maximum of $1.61 million per player. MLS fined the club $2 million and reduced its allocation dollars by $2.27 million for the 2022 and 2023 seasons, while Mas was fined $250,000 and McDonough was suspended from league activities through the end of the 2022 season.{{cite press release |date=May 28, 2021 |title=MLS Announces Sanctions for Inter Miami CF Violating League Salary Budget and Roster Guidelines |url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/news/mls-announces-sanctions-for-inter-miami-cf-violating-league-salary-budget-and-ro |publisher=Major League Soccer |accessdate=June 16, 2021}} Prior to the announcement, Matuidi was reclassified as a Designated Player by taking the slot occupied by [[Matías Pellegrini]], who was loaned to [[Inter Miami CF II]] after his contract was bought out by the club.{{cite news |last=Kaufman |first=Michelle |date=May 28, 2021 |title=MLS slaps Inter Miami with a record $2 million fine for violating roster rules in 2020 |url=https://www.miamiherald.com/sports/mls/inter-miami/article251746813.html |work=The Miami Herald |accessdate=June 16, 2021 |archive-date=June 24, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210624203423/https://www.miamiherald.com/sports/mls/inter-miami/article251746813.html |url-status=live }} === Messi era (2023–present) === [[File:CINvMIA 2023-08-23 - Lionel Messi, Tata Martino (PXL 20230824 010525464) (Messi crop).jpg|thumb|Argentine attacker [[Lionel Messi]] signed with Miami in July 2023.]] On June 1, 2023, Inter Miami announced that the club had parted ways with Neville. At the time, the club was placed last in the Eastern Conference.{{cite web|date=June 1, 2023|title=Inter Miami CF Parts Ways With Phil Neville|url=https://www.intermiamicf.com/news/inter-miami-cf-parts-ways-with-phil-neville|access-date=June 1, 2023|publisher=Inter Miami CF|archive-date=June 1, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230601221446/https://www.intermiamicf.com/news/inter-miami-cf-parts-ways-with-phil-neville|url-status=live}} Four days later, the seven-time [[Ballon d'Or]] winner [[Lionel Messi]] announced his intention to join the club as a free agent after leaving [[Paris Saint-Germain]], turning down an offer to play for [[Saudi Pro League]] club [[Al-Hilal SFC|Al-Hilal]] and ruling out a return to [[FC Barcelona]].{{cite news |last1=Balague |first1=Guillem |date=June 7, 2023 |title='I've taken the decision' – Messi to join Inter Miami |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/65832658 |website=BBC Sport |access-date=June 10, 2023}} Messi signed his Designated Player contract on July 15, 2023, joining the team through the 2025 MLS season.{{cite news|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/news/official-lionel-messi-signs-with-inter-miami|title=Official! Lionel Messi signs with Inter Miami|first=Jonathan|last=Sigal|publisher=mlssoccer.com|date=July 15, 2023|accessdate=July 15, 2023}} Argentine and former Barça manager [[Gerardo Martino|Tata Martino]] was appointed as the head coach of the club on June 28 and joined Miami the following month.{{cite news |last=Sklar |first=Sam |date=July 10, 2023 |title=Tata Martino begins first day as Inter Miami coach as Messi's debut nears |url=https://www.sun-sentinel.com/2023/07/10/its-really-natural-tata-martino-begins-first-day-as-inter-miami-head-coach/ |work=Sun Sentinel |accessdate=July 19, 2023}} Messi formally joined the team, alongside former Barcelona teammate [[Sergio Busquets]], at an unveiling ceremony on July 16.{{cite news |last=Miller Degnan |first=Susan |date=July 17, 2023 |title=Newest Inter Miami megastar Sergio Busquets celebrates birthday with Messi and fans |url=https://www.miamiherald.com/sports/mls/inter-miami/article277287688.html |work=Miami Herald |accessdate=July 19, 2023}} Five days later, another of his former Barcelona teammates, [[Jordi Alba]], also signed for Inter Miami.{{cite web |date=July 20, 2023 |title=Inter Miami CF Signs Spanish International Defender Jordi Alba |url=https://www.intermiamicf.com/news/inter-miami-cf-signs-spanish-international-defender-jordi-alba |publisher=Inter Miami CF}} Following Messi's arrival, resale ticket prices for his first games with the club increased by over 1,000%.
